bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, June 3, 1940

div1.p: Hench congratulates Moran on his award of the Grand Cross of the Order of Finlay. He is very busy with professional responsibilities, but promises to return to his yellow fever notes soon.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, June 3, 1940
div1.opener:
yellow fever
June 3, 1940
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
I cannot tell you how delighted I was to hear that
you were to receive the Grand Cross of the Order of Finley.
Your letter to Mr. Moran was a beauty, but you were entirely
too kind to me. If I did instigate this matter, as you very
well know, I did so completely unwittingly. I didn't even
know there was such a medal until I got to Havana, and the
only possible contribution that I made was to show the Cuban
government how interested others were and how much we thought
of your contribution. If this served to awaken them to the fact
that they had not honored you sufficiently, I am indeed proud
and delighted at this small by-product of my trip.

I have been extremely busy, as I told you I would be,
cince returning. I am to receive an honorary degree from my
Alma Mater next week, and as President of the American Rheuma-
tism Association, will preside at our meetings in New York.
I expect to see General Kean on my return through Washington
and thereafter will get down to work on my notes and data of
my Havana trip.
You will hear from me very shortly thereafter.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
